urn:contentItem:59WR-3H91-JB20-G2D1-00000-00ServiceNow at UBS Global Technology Conference - Final2013-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:40ZLexisNexis112013a5213314.714ServiceNow at UBS Global Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Frank Slootman

ServiceNow, Inc. - President, CEO

* Mike Scarpelli

ServiceNow, Inc. - CFO

Conference Call Participants

* Brent Thill

UBS - Analyst

Presentation

BRENT THILL, ANALYST, UBS: Good morning, everyone. My name is Brent Thill. I am responsible for the software research initiative at UBS. Thanks for joining us today. We're really excited to have you at Cavallo Point. This is a unique setting. Sorry we don't have a better view of the Golden Gate Bridge this morning, but I think you will be able to see it later in the day.

After multiple months with no rain, it had to come right during our conference, so I apologize for that.

But on a brighter note, we have Frank Slootman, CEO, and Mike Scarpelli, CFO, of ServiceNow. Many of you have heard this story, but I think it's one of the more unique stories in our space, and they're really redefining a really new opportunity that we think is extremely exciting. Both Frank and Mike, obviously, were at Data Domain before they joined ServiceNow, so they worked together in the past and worked very well together, as you'll see on this presentation.

We are going to turn it over to Frank for just a few opening remarks, and then we will go to Q&A and we will take Q&A from all of you. If there is anything we can do for you during the day, please don't hesitate to reach out. There is no request that we can't handle.

We will have the ServiceNow self-service portal outside here to help, too. We can route the request, and then Kirsten Parker is running our tech initiative from the distribution side, if you raise your hand, get to know her. She is based in London and is responsible for all of our tech products, so I want to make sure we highlighted her work here today as well.

Thanks, and Frank, we appreciate you being here.

FRANK SLOOTMAN, PRESIDENT, CEO, SERVICENOW, INC.: Yes, so good morning, everybody. Do a little bit of prepared remarks here for those of you that don't know the story very well or you are just getting acquainted, some things that we really want you to take away, and then all the Q&A part will be a little bit more pointed for those of you who have been following us a lot more closely.

Safely into harbor, thank you. Our starting point is always, with ServiceNow, is that we bill ourselves as the enterprise IT cloud. As you know, Salesforce, sales and marketing clouds; Workday and HR clouds; NetSuite, finance clouds. Lots of marketing clouds out there.

We are that one company that is squarely focused on the enterprise IT audience. That is our constituency. We always tell IT audiences, IT is our home and you guys are our homies, and it's really important because that's the advocacy that we leverage inside the enterprise.

The second thing is this is a very high-growth enterprise. Literally out of the gate, the Company bootstrapped itself back in 2004 with less than $10 million in capital and never looked back, and on the compound annual basis, has been growing, has been doubling in size literally every year. Even in our most recent quarter, on a revenue basis year on year, it was 73% growth. So it takes a lot to grow at that rate, and I will emphasize it a little bit more.

Final point here, we did move our head office to Silicon Valley. We are originally a San Diego company. We have been in San Diego for a long time, but we have now really spread out the West Coast. We are in Seattle now. We have several hundred people in our new head office in Santa Clara, right here on 101.

Now, the takeaways. The first thing that we emphasize about ourselves is that even though we go to market with a portfolio of applications, we are fundamentally a software platform company and the applications are built on our platform. The platform is really the power behind the throne. It is what enables -- it is what allows applications to be built very, very quickly, really orders of magnitude faster than what people have historically been able to do. And that's why the name of the Company is ServiceNow, not later.

Also, this system was built in such a way that applications can very, very quickly morph and change. They are super dynamic. What is important about that is that you don't have to get it right up front. It is not like carving a tombstone, like once the app is built, you never touch it again type of thing. Applications iterate very quickly, typically on a daily basis. So it's a very, very modern approach to building applications.

Now, the platform is relatively generic. It can build applications for any kind of service function throughout the enterprise, but we focus the application portfolio on the needs of internal IT, most notably IT service management, instant management, problem management, change management, configuration management. These are disciplines that are very well known, very precisely defined and understood in IT organizations.

But ServiceNow is used by the vast majority of our customers not just inside IT, but also outside of IT, and also in customer-facing applications. So that significantly increases the total addressable market. It is really a multiple of what we think the IT opportunity is for us.

We are very focused on large enterprises. The bigger your IT budgets are, the more IT people you have, the more value there is, typically, in deploying ServiceNow. We have about 1,900 customers as of the end of last quarter. About 360 of those are Global 2000 entities, so those are names anybody would recognize.

We are a SaaS Company, so we have a ratable revenue recognition model, very high predictability, very strong cash flow, so those are the good aspects of the model here.

Our customers are not really concentrated in any one vertical. We're in big tech, we're in big pharma, we're in big retail. We're public sector, state and local. General Electric is our largest customer, general industrial type stuff. They literally manage service providers, global outsourcers. Everywhere there is IT, you will find ServiceNow.

Now this is a new picture that we have inserted in our investor presentation, and it's really to create some perspective on what is the growth opportunity for ServiceNow over the long haul. Today, we are -- last 12 months' revenue, around $400 million, very similar to Workday. We have very similar scale, very similar growth pattern. Obviously, they are higher on the market cap side.

We really believe that on the strength of our pure IT ascent opportunity -- I will explain a little bit more about that -- that the Company has lines of sight in the next two years to get to the $1 billion revenue run rate.

But the question then becomes what happens after that. What is sort of your next major mile marker in terms of what you're aiming for in terms of growth and scale? Could we aspire to be a Salesforce class company in terms of revenues and so on, and what would that take? I will explain how we think, what our strategies are to get to that level, and then the question becomes, can you dream even bigger and aspire to get into the classes of the very, very large software companies in this space?

So this is important because one of the great things that so attracted me to ServiceNow 2.5 years ago is that this Company is really unbounded in terms of its addressable market opportunity, and it was very evident, because the Company has bled into all aspects of the enterprise, as well as beyond the enterprise in terms of customer facing, really without the Company even trying. And that is because of the advocacy role that IT departments play in the enterprise.

So this is probably one of the most important pictures I can show you. As many of you know, we have our DNA set, if you will, going all the way back to the mid-1990s. We didn't exist then as a company, but our founder, Fred Luddy, was the Chief Technology Officer of Peregrine Systems and Remedy software back in those days. And in 2004 when he started ServiceNow, he said I started ServiceNow really to atone for my sins, because he won't have to basically go after a lot of the systemic issues that has plagued that generation of software.

But help desk was the first service model that came into the enterprise to help IT organizations. In the mid-2000s, help desk really evolved into what we now call IT service management, and that was really under the influence of the IT infrastructure library framework, right? It was a precise set of definitions and it really superseded the notion of help desk as a service model.

It also drastically expanded the marketplace because in the days of help desk, you just licensed to people that were physically on the help desk, right? In the days of ITSM, everybody who was an owner of a part of the infrastructure, whether it was a server or a database or a virtual machine or a network, whatever it was, they were part of the workflow, and the same thing on the application side, right? Anybody who was an owner of an application or a piece of an application, they became part of it.

That's one of the things that was not understood at the time of our IPO is that ITSM was really an order of magnitude greater opportunity than the historical help desk of the mid-1990s.

We had to push the boundaries of ITSM even bigger to a notion that we refer to as ERP for IT. And ERP for IT, really everybody in the IT organization is really an actor and a participant in the workflow, and it becomes really the system of record for that function. And that's been a very strong driving part of our vision.

Now, what has happened in our business, and this is super important to appreciate what's going on at ServiceNow, is that IT organizations, and particularly the IT executives, CIOs and so on, they have taken the IT service model and recognized that it is actually very easy to adapt and repurpose for service domains beyond IT.

So you very typically see ServiceNow showing up in human resources. Human resources has historically not had a service model, right? They had email. If you had issues and you needed help from HR, what did you do? You sent them an email and hoped the hell that somebody would get back to you and it wouldn't go into a black hole.

The same thing with facilities. They don't have service models, either. You manage outsource, that stuff typically has been done through email as well. So this whole notion of having service models and service management systems is actually relatively new when you get outside of the parameters of the enterprise IT function.

So this is something that has been catching fire, because people very quickly start to recognize how easy it is to apply these service models to functions that have traditionally been dealt with on email, spreadsheets, personal databases, and so on. So I will talk about that more.

So ServiceNow, we refer to the platform as a service automation platform. I will explain to you what service relationships really are and what service automation really is. It is actually a devastatingly simple concept, but we recognize it differently.

So that service automation platform really established in the IT organization people that understand service models, very well defined, very mature. So that is where we land and that is why we use the advocacy of the IT organization.

What has happened is the service platform has really been pushing out in all these other functional areas. Just as we have needs of IT organization, we have needs of all these other organizations as well, but everybody can become either a requester or a provider of a service.

And I say a service, it can just be a request, literally, for a service or a product. It can just be information, can be help, can be a change, anything that anybody can possibly ask for.

Now, service relationship management, there are people that need something and there is people that can provide the services. The providers of the services are not necessarily people. Typically, they are systems or systems that are actually assisted by people. And a lot of the provisioning these days of service requests is done in a highly automated fashion -- no hands, speed of light, lights out.

But what is different when you do this in a system rather than on email is that we actually define what the service is. Now you go, what do you mean by definition? When I sent somebody an email, I am defining what I'm asking for. That is actually unstructured, right?

What you do in a service management system, you actually have a very precise data definition of what that service is. What that lets you do is aggregate the data and create reporting metrics -- dashboarding and analytics around it, and you can actually ask the question, what were the top three things that HR worked on in this particular location over this particular period of time? You can't do that when you have emails. So how do you actually manage relationships if you don't even know what people are working on?

Secondly, the provisioning of services actually happens through a defined workflow, as opposed to who you know running around the building type of thing and constantly following up with the status of my PO, blah, blah, blah, that sort of thing. So building these things into systems has been a very, very powerful thing for us.

And then, finally, automation. Automation is really the mantra of the cloud. The opportunity to disintermediate these processes is just enormous.

We have one of our large financial institution customers, they got 35,000 IT people on service. Now, they were telling us we're going to take in 2014 1,000 people on IT strictly through automation. IT organizations tend to be overstaffed, underautomated, and the opportunity to start inverting that equation is incredible. Taking 1,000 people out is dropping $100 million to the bottom line. You better believe that matters, and you look at IT staffs around the world, they are huge. So the opportunity to go after savings and efficiency there is phenomenal.

Now, what we're really after here with service relationship management is really to create a new class of software. 15 years ago, we really didn't know what ERP was, and we certainly didn't know what CRM was, either, right? ERP really grew out of a variety of applications, general ledger and accounts receivable and so on, and gradually that -- and spreadsheets, by the way, and then gradually, that really became a real suite of systems, really typically owned by the Chief Financial Officer really integrating all the back-office operations.

More recently, we have seen this similar phenomenon in the front office, notably Salesforce really driving the notion of a sales and marketing and the service cloud. Once front office -- and by the way, that is where the CMO is really the dominant owner of the systems.

So we view the CIO, Chief Information Officer, as really being the guy or the gal in the middle and that really manages the work and the service relationships that exist between these departments. And you are, like, well, I can't really see this opportunity. That's right because today it lives in Lotus Notes, it lives in SharePoint, it lives in tons of spreadsheets.

You go to large institutions. I know at UBS, the CIO told us one time, yes, we've got 5,000 systems, 4,975. Actually our spreadsheets are Microsoft Access personal databases. Every large institution has thousands and thousands and thousands of these small applications lying around that are service oriented, and it's a huge problem because a lot of them are on laptops. They are sitting in the back of cars. They are not secure, they are not compliant, they are not multi-user. They are just not enterprise grade, and they're old. The people that have built them have long gone. So there is really this incredible opportunity for an IT organization to establish common platform for this kind of activity and work.

So that's our ambition, to establish the category that way.

Now this is how everybody knows IT. We make a request of IT -- my printer is out of toner. Can you please help? But these days, most requests coming into IT are not coming from people anymore; they are coming from machines. Events are raised in the infrastructure; events programmatically become incidents. Incidents are effectively the initiation of a structured workflow. A lot of that is not people to people; it is literally system to system. Now we are a long ways away from the world of help desk here.

But I can change this relationship very easy. Sometimes we refer to this as the monkey in the middle. IT goes out of the middle; now HR becomes the service provider and everybody else the requester. HR can really run the exact same service model that IT does. Many of our customers actually take our applications and just repurpose them for HR, and when I say repurpose, they just rename them.

HR people don't like to talk about incidents; they call them cases. No big deal. It's exactly the same thing, but they have their own terminology and their own words and their own nomenclature, and it's so easy to do. The notion to sequence of incident, problem, and change, which is so typical for IT people, applies to any service domain. This is essentially a way of managing service.

General Electric does this for turbines. We have people that do it for x-ray machines; Intel does it for lab equipment. So any physical or even nonphysical asset can be the subject of these kinds of service models.

So we believe, and we [focelate] this a lot with our CIO audience, that the future of IT and particularly the CIO really is in the management of service in the enterprise. You think about it, IT is in a bit of a precarious spot because infrastructure is moving to the cloud, slowly but surely, fits and starts, and that has been the dominant preoccupation of IT is running infrastructure, keeping the lights on.

A lot of the apps are moving to the line of business. Certainly, Salesforce is running around saying CMOs have had more budget now than CIOs. That's true. What is IT going to do? What is going to be their mission and their goal in life?

So this whole notion of managing service, shared services, throughout the enterprise, we believe, is the opportunity for IT. We can work so much better through disintermediation. We can do so much more with less. We can really manage for service performance and we have an opportunity to really impact the service experience itself.

Standing in line for service is just very awful. We always take pictures around the world when we travel, what are the worst service experiences on the planet? DMV is probably near the top. US Postal Service, immigration, and we have so many -- there are so many instructive places where we can learn about a really superior service experience. You can go to Amazon, you can go to Expedia, online banking, and this is really what IT can do for the world is really bring a service experience that is consumerized, really world class, and is something where we want to go, as opposed to somewhere that we have to go.

Real quickly, one of our big inspirations for our strategy was actually the city of CERN. CERN is actually not a city; it is a nuclear research organization in Europe on the French/Swiss border, but there is 700 buildings and 30,000 scientists that travel through there, and they run the entire city of CERN on ServiceNow. They essentially defined a services taxonomy; I think there is 650 services.

This is all the stuff in every walk of life or any category of service that scientists can request, whether it is transportation, whether it is lodging, whether it is entertainment, whether it is food, help, facilities. You see all the things that a regular city has, CERN has as well.

That concept has really taken off because this is the notion of a service model. And a lot of our business partners are really pursuing different verticals, lines of business, developing standard service models that they can wholesale, deliver through their customers, as opposed to something that we are going to build from scratch every single time.

Why now? The technology is making it so much easier, faster, and cheaper. Outsourcing drives a lot of this, right, because you can't manage service relationships, outsourcing relationships, without systems. Regulated industries, they got to prove they are following a defined workflow, and of course, mobile. People are not in offices, but they are in hospitals, schools, or in the field. It dramatically opens up the opportunity for automation.

So with that, I would like to wrap this up, sit down, and see if we can answer some questions. This is our management group. As you said, Mike and I have worked together -- actually, most of our management team has been together for a very long time. It is kind of a unique story in the industry for people having worked together in two companies now for the better part of seven or eight years.

With that, I will put this away and I will sit down.

Questions and Answers

BRENT THILL: Thanks, Frank. We will open it up to questions. If you have a question, please raise your hand. I have questions to get it going. So this is your conference, but just to maybe kick it off.

Just from -- the biggest question we get from investors is how you measure your TAM as you move beyond a broader service automation market. Is it easy enough to put a single number on it or is it too complex because it is this moving target every year? Salesforce talked about this yesterday. They raised their TAM by a pretty big order of magnitude, almost $18 billion within a year. So is this --

FRANK SLOOTMAN: The interesting thing is people like Workday because they can see a very big TAM, in terms of the business that SAP and Oracle does. But it takes talent to hit a target that nobody else can hit, but it takes genius to hit a target that nobody else can see.

And a lot of what we do is transformational. It is not totally visible to the world. Do you really believe that people are going to really implement these service relationships systems versus keep running 20-year-old spreadsheets and email-type paradigm? Yes, it takes a little bit of a leap of faith.

But you come to our users conference and we have -- in May in Vegas, we had 4,000 people, even though we only had 1,500 customers at the time. We had 4,000 people show up. Next year, we are expecting 6,000 to 7,000 here in San Francisco. The place is just buzzing with all the opportunities that people are pursuing to implement the technology in ways you cannot even get your head around.

I travel almost every week and it is extraordinarily inspiring to see what people do with the platform. That is why my first words out of my mouth are we are a platform company. This is not about the apps. We can literally go anywhere with the apps. We just love the IT opportunity because that is a market you can see. We are replacing 10-, 15-year-old software.

And you can look at our rate of monetization. We have about 18% penetration, of which probably a third saturated in terms of opportunity.

You can see what our revenue run rate is. There is about 12,000 enterprises that we think are appropriate and applicable to our business, and you do the math on that, the IT opportunity alone is in the $8 billion to $10 billion of spend. You get outside of IT, you're dealing with a multiple of that size. I don't know how big that multiple is. Maybe it is a multiple of [1]. I can't authoritatively put that number on it because it is not a market that has metastasized to the point where you can really do that.

BRENT THILL: Let's bring Mike into this conversation. Your run rate, you are running the $0.5 billion run rate, and your growth rate, you effectively don't have too many people at that type of growth. Can you just help us understand how you're putting the right infrastructure in and sales processes in to help? As many companies have hit that milestone and hit a speed bump, you don't seem like you're at all feeling any resistance on your wings, if you will.

MIKE SCARPELLI, CFO, SERVICENOW, INC.: I think we -- I joined the Company slightly after Frank, a little over almost 2.5 years ago, I guess, a little over two years ago, and one of the first things I did when I saw that growth is -- I think we hire the right people. We put in place the right systems. We still have a lot of improvement, especially on the sales automation side, but we are rolling that out right now and I feel pretty comfortable with what we are doing with preparing for that growth.

The biggest challenge we had with this Company that I never had before is how geographically dispersed we are as a Company and the burden that it puts on facilities. A lot of people don't realize when you're adding -- we will have added north of 700 people this year. We think next year we are probably going to add 700 to 800 people. The problem is is forecasting when those people are going to go and making sure that you don't overcommit yourself to a facility.

We made some mistakes early on on the facility side. We fixed that. You saw some of those charges we took early on in 2012, but we think we have the right people in place to scale the Company.

It is really the people. The systems are there, too. We run on SAP and we're using a lot of our own internal -- our own product for our own internal systems as well. We built a procurement system that we just went live with. There is a bunch of other systems that we are building as well.

We built out our own sales force on our own product method. We're going to sell that as an app, but it has all the functionality for us internally with the pipeline and the weighting and managing that as well. We manage all of our customers from a support perspective through our own product.

BRENT THILL: You had (multiple speakers)

FRANK SLOOTMAN: (multiple speakers) infrastructure is run on our platform.

BRENT THILL: A few questions from investors around the pricing. You had, I think, a minor update to the pricing. Can you just crystallize what you did and why you did it?

FRANK SLOOTMAN: When we joined the Company, there was one price and it bought you everything, and half the customers loved it, like this is great. You are not nickel and diming me. The other half hated it because they didn't want to pay for everything that they weren't using. So it was a no-win situation.

And as time wore on, we decided that we were going to morph the pricing model to much more of an a la carte thing. In other words, you could buy exactly what you wanted, pay for that, and you could expand your usage as you went along. If you were not using our platform to build custom bespoke apps, then don't pay for that. But if you do, then we will charge you for that.

We have basically entry-level bundles of software now that just lets you commit to the platform at a number that is more amenable for people that don't want to step up to the whole thing.

So that is really the change in pricing strategy for new customers. They don't know any better, so it is what it is. That is our model. When we do renewals, obviously we have to take people through the transition of the model, but that's just part of doing business.

We're also, obviously, trying to monetize our business more intelligently, but most important is reduce friction in the sales process.

MIKE SCARPELLI: It also helps us be more scalable because you don't have reps coming for exception pricing all the time, because you have certain customers that only value a certain component of our offering, and now we can offer those as separate SKUs. And we feel we are not going to leave as much money on the table with those upsells in the future with those customers.

FRANK SLOOTMAN: We have customers like Volkswagen, who has a massive service catalog application across the enterprise with 800,000 people on it. That is just what they wanted to do. They look at our product, I just want to buy that.

Our pricing model was not set up for that, so it takes a lot of negotiating and a lot of work. So we wanted to make that just easier and really build those kind of options into the model.

BRENT THILL: Mike, you gave very encouraging billing guidance for Q4, and maybe if you can work back and just help us understand what you're seeing in the customer behavior to get to such a strong number in terms of what you are seeing in contract size and duration. Any trends, high-level trends, that maybe highlight the strength of your business?

MIKE SCARPELLI: Sure, contract length has been pretty consistent, new business. It runs 35 months on average. Remember, we incent our sales force to sell a three-year contract with 12 months' billings in advance, which, by the way, we are seeing less and less of those multiple-year payments in advance.

You'll notice last quarter was actually the lowest at only 4% of our billings were multiple years, and that's on purpose. We are not incentivizing the sales force because the customers we deal with, there is no credit issues with those.

Remember, a big chunk of our billings is not necessarily just the new business we sign in the quarter. A lot of it is our backlog, as we are building our backlog. There is professional services that go into that as well, too. And based upon what we are seeing with our backlog that I know is going to be billed this quarter, we feel very confident that the guidance I gave when I was asked the question was plus $150 million or north of $150 million.

BRENT THILL: 50% plus?

MIKE SCARPELLI: I feel pretty good about that number.

BRENT THILL: Great.

MIKE SCARPELLI: You got to remember, we added a lot of people in our sales and marketing organization the first half of this year. We are now starting to see a lot of those reps going to full productivity because it is a nine-month ramp, so Q4 we are seeing a lot of those reps and the benefit of those. We see it in the pipeline with the deals right now.

BRENT THILL: You had a great slide, which basically showed the leaders in the cloud, which you are one of them. Our simple thesis has been there is going to be a front office and a back office and the service and the traveling expense, and maybe an infrastructure, but there will be some big clouds that are going to take over. And I think just being in the city yesterday at Salesforce's event with 130,000-plus people, you see this whole industry almost hitting the tipping point now.

From your perspective, what do you think is left for this to really continue to hit, or have we hit this now and the old-school vendors just can't even catch this now because they are so poorly architected and their business models are built for the past?

FRANK SLOOTMAN: Yes, I think the business model is probably the least of their issues. I think -- we call it Soviet-era software. It is so backward, it is almost unapproachable for today's generation of people that have to work with it.

We have customers that, initial instance, would not go with us and picked up a CA or a BMC or whatever, and then a year later, they are, like, are we stupid that we can't do this? It is not that they are stupid; it's just generationally there is so much separation between the people that have to do it and the technology, from what era it comes from. And it is not just that it is not that good, it's that people simply are just wholesale failing with it.

So having a modern architecture, a modern platform, and the changes are just phenomenal what is possible today versus before. I don't think there's enough appreciation out there. People really do not fully understand what these differences are.

The consumer approach by Amazon, Google, Expedia, and so on has really given the enterprise sector to become much better than they have ever been. Our Company was founded -- Fred Luddy was inspired by Yahoo and Google. He was like that is what enterprise software should be like. Salesforce is a generation before that, but also made huge headway on that front.

This are very important things because it makes the platform more approachable. More people can get productive on the platform. We're a nonprogrammer platform. There is no procedural language. That expands your population by orders of magnitude. Anybody who has an Excel spreadsheet, and I am sure everybody in this room touches Excel, you can build apps on our platform. That is a statement you could ever make in prior generation.

BRENT THILL: The question on competition comes up, and clearly Salesforce is not going to walk away without giving up the fight on the service angle. And they talked about Philips embedding a service button right in the MRI machine yesterday, where they could just hit and the technician could get help driven right from the machine. When you think about where they're going and where you are at, you mentioned GE. Both are customers of respective companies. It seems like there is room for both of you right now, given your focus and given how big this market is.

FRANK SLOOTMAN: Yes, we think there is. And the reason is we're not presumptuous enough to say we do everything for everybody. We are all things to all people.

We build a certain class of applications really, really well. That is why we have a high level of abstraction. We are not a generic programming platform the way Salesforce is. That said, we do come head to head. You mentioned GE. We had a confrontation there with GE Energy, which we won. All the warranty claims processing of power turbines and things like that all runs on ServiceNow.

But what our customers will tell you is that the application is appropriate for ServiceNow. We are an order of magnitude cheaper and faster than Salesforce in terms of the implementation.

But I gave you a caveat. In other words, not every app is appropriate for us. We look for these workflow request/response type of applications.

But Salesforce is much more generic. It is aiming at a lower level of developer. They may not be aiming for it, but it requires a lower level of developer than what ServiceNow does. The guy from GE Energy said to us at the conference, he said it took us longer to decide than actually build and roll out a fully deployed system. That's how inverted things are these days. People spend more time talking that actually delivering stuff.

BRENT THILL: I will ask you one more and then we can open it up. Just from a sales force capacity, it seems like you have the right platform now. Now you are probably bound more by distribution capacity than anything. Can you give us a sense of how that buildout has been going this year, how you think about the next year?

MIKE SCARPELLI: We were actually working on it yesterday, our 2014 headcount plan for sales.

So we entered the year with 350 people in our sales and marketing organization. Our plan was to exit with 600. We very much front-end loaded that. We're going to do somewhere around 610 we are going to exit, so slightly ahead of plan.

Next year, we anticipate that we are going to hire a similar amount, 250, 270 people into the sales and marketing organization. There is going to be a focus on a lot of developing markets. We really moving into Asia-Pacific. We're going to go heavier in Latin America, South America as well. And we are really focused on where are the Global 2000.

We are seeing that kind of nine-month ramp time for developed territories for reps. These new geographies we're going into, like Japan was one that we went into, that is a 15-month, plus, ramp cycle. On average, we think it is about 15 months to ramp in new territories.

You don't want to add too fast, though, especially in your existing territories, because you disincent your existing salespeople. You got to give them plenty of notice when you're going to split territories to close deals. If not, you will lose people. Remember, your best source of finding people is through your existing people, and you want them to be happy. And happy for a salesperson is knowing they can make a good W-2.

FRANK SLOOTMAN: Sales cycles are longer, actually. You cannot just sort of willy-nilly yank territories around because they're working all these transactions for many, many months.

MIKE SCARPELLI: This is an ERP-type sale. It does not happen overnight. It doesn't mean that it takes them that nine months to make the decision, but our customers do not pull the trigger until they're ready to do the implementation, because as soon as they sign the contract, the subscription starts, and they want to make sure that they plan their own internal resources to do the deployment.

BRENT THILL: Great. Do we have any questions?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Recently, there was a Piper survey that says that the top cloud winners, and you guys are obviously in the top five, which surprised me, just given your size, along with names like Amazon, Google, salesforce.com, then ServiceNow.

FRANK SLOOTMAN: Why did that surprise you?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: It surprised me given your size, and Workday and other names are not on the top five. So I'm wondering if you have made a concerted effort to get a mind share of CIOs. These are CIOs who get -- who did the survey. So the question was (multiple speakers) you do that?

FRANK SLOOTMAN: You are exactly right. We do make a concerted effort to address the executive audience. Because I said this during the prepared remarks, we're really trying to give IT organizations a forward strategy because they are in transition.

Things are going to change. IT is not staying where it had been with a screwdriver out and they are having the wiring closet and keeping the lights on and running around with their hair on fire. That model is going away.

IT is going to split between infrastructure and apps, and the infrastructure is moving to the cloud, whether we like it or not. It may be slowly in some places, but it is going to. So IT people need to develop a different approach of what they are in the enterprise. A lot of apps are going to be in other places, so they are embracing ServiceNow.

I saw a CIO the other day in New York at a large insurance company, and he said, look, ServiceNow is my service hub. That is the term that he used, not our term. He says it's the hub; it's the fabric; it's where all service relationships get implemented and managed. So therefore, we have high mind share with these people because we are central to their mission, much more so than other players.

The contrast between us and Salesforce is Salesforce is trying to get into the enterprise from the outside in. They are going after sales. They are going after marketing. They're going after customer support.

We come from the inside out through IT. So IT is our advocacy. It is our landing ground, and then from there through IT and with the advocacy of IT. Salesforce is always surprised when they see us, because where did you people come from, because you didn't get there the way we did. So it's a completely inverted go-to-market model that we have, compared to them.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I like to think you like to keep your sales people happy. Just a question in terms of you talked about the other opportunities, so you referenced HR, but then at the user conference, you also say that there are other things that you are discussing. Can you talk about where else within an organization you are actually starting to see interest in deploying ServiceNow, please? Thank you.

FRANK SLOOTMAN: Yes, so the -- I call them service adjacencies. In other words, organizations that are highly analogous to IT is typically low-hanging fruit.

People can have a very clear line of sight. Okay, we're going to do HR because the service model is the same; facilities, the same thing. At UBS, your travel requests are running on ServiceNow. That is how you get permission to travel here from London, presumably, stuff like that. Or even legal organizations do it that way.

But you mentioned the Philips app with Salesforce. We have a customer in Belgium, [acva], who builds x-ray machines for hospitals, and they -- actually, they are in the middle of going live with this system right now. And they have deployed ServiceNow exactly the same way. So in other words, doctors and nurses in hospitals interact with the manufacturer through ServiceNow.

So we are in that same category of customer-facing applications. We have a very large retailer who uses us for balancing supply chains, because this store doesn't have enough of this and that store has too much of this. This constant process of rebalancing inventories between stores and distribution centers, they do on ServiceNow.

So these are examples that are farther afield from the typical service domain that we all know about through our normal work lives. But it is mind blowing because it is an infinite set of things. Everything that is request/response/workflow oriented is fair game for our platform. And you don't need programmers to stand up these apps, and apps are stood up in hours and days, not in weeks and months. So there is an order of magnitude speed difference in how quickly you can show something.

It is a very different mentality toward standing up applications, sort of what spreadsheets did to the world. All of a sudden, it just exploded application development. Why? Because everybody can use it.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: What are the (inaudible) challenges to adoption? Do IT departments often feel threatened by you? And you said a lot of them are overstaffed. Do they worry that more efficient means they're going to have to be cutting their colleagues? Or when people don't take you, what is the reason, typically?

FRANK SLOOTMAN: The automation is a mixed blessing because the executives love it, but the workforce gets a little uneasy on that value proposition.

But the friction in our model is really that these are systems that are replacing systems that have been around for a long time, 10, 15 times, often times very heavily customized, very heavily integrated. People don't really know how they work. They are afraid to turn them off; they don't know how to turn them off. They don't know how to sequence themselves through that process.

Like Mike said, it is like an ERP deployment. It is very high profile. When these systems are not working, everybody knows about it. So this really has to be a very highly prioritized project. It is not something you push out and go, like, put me down for one of those and we will turn it on on Monday. Not like that. This is a very serious deployment.

The systems are very sticky because as lousy as these legacy systems are, they are not that easy to pull out. That is the friction that we deal with. That is why we have a sales force; otherwise, we'd just have a fax machine.

BRENT THILL: Great. Frank, Mike, thanks for your time. Appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:5PJ4-JHH1-DY2R-21Y5-00000-00SESTA is flawed, but the debate over it welcome;Online regulation2017-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:40ZLexisNexisLEADERSESTA is flawed, but the debate over it welcomeOnline regulation

The internet has grown up, and so must its biggest companies

ONCE the giants of the internet could do no wrong. Now they are a favourite target of politicians everywhere. Europe's finance ministers are discussing ways to increase taxes on digital services. Theresa May, Britain's prime minister, this week demanded that social-media platforms be able to take down terrorist material within two hours. In America Facebook's bosses must soon tell Congress what role users tied to Russia played in last year's presidential campaign.

Much of this is still political theatre. But not all. America's Senate is contemplating the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act (SESTA), a bipartisan bill that seeks to deter sex trafficking by ensuring that the Communications Decency Act (CDA) does not protect online services, such as Backpage.com, notorious for making money with sex-trafficking ads (see page 66). Should the bill pass, a wave of lawsuits against social-media platforms is likely to follow.

SESTA highlights a growing problem with which many governments are grappling: how online firms should be held liable for illegal content that is published on their platforms. From October, Germany will require firms to take down hate speech and fake news within 24 hours, or face fines of up to ?50m ($60m). Yet the debate over SESTA is especially important. It could end up being the model for other areas, chilling free speech and innovation.

If the internet and some of the firms it has spawned have taken over the world, this is the result not simply of entrepreneurial brilliance but also of an implicit subsidy. In America and Europe online platforms have until now inhabited a parallel legal universe. Broadly speaking, relevant media laws—in particular the CDA—exempt them from liability for what their users do or for the harm that their services can cause.

This made sense in the early days of the internet, when it was still a sideshow. Ruinous lawsuits might have crushed then-infant digital ventures. But today online firms have come to dominate entire industries. They can also no longer be considered neutral conduits for information, like telecoms carriers. Facebook's algorithms, for instance, determine what members see in their news feeds. The words and deeds of online ghouls have consequences in the real world.

SESTA has a worthy aim. Yet it is too broad. It greatly expands the definition of enabling sex trafficking, including ten actions, from advertising to transporting. It would also let state attorneys-general and civil claimants sue online platforms. A deluge of lawsuits is likely. In general, big tech firms can afford such programmes, but startups may face bankruptcy. Both will want to avoid trouble by erring on the side of safety, curbing free speech.

Rather than attempt to define precisely what material is banned—which invites arguments—the law should instead require firms only to follow a reasonable, transparent process by which they decide what to take down. That would cover sites like Backpage.com and limit potential lawsuits. It should take into account differences in size. Smaller firms could be held to a different standard, depending on their resources and business models. Widely accessible sites could be more tightly regulated than those with a restricted audience.

The drawback is that this turns online firms, especially big ones, into arbiters of acceptable speech. But it would be preferable to a series of all-controlling, SESTA-like laws, which could ultimately turn them into regulated utilities (see Schumpeter). To avoid that fate, they need to realise that, as the dominant actors of the digital age, they bear special responsibility.

urn:contentItem:5RX2-D421-JDJN-6142-00000-00Setting the boundary lines in the content wars2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:40ZLexisNexisSetting the boundary lines in the content warsCecilia Kang

A US court will have the final word on whether AT&T can go ahead with $85b Time Warner merger deal, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years

By Cecilia Kang

How you watch "Game of Thrones" and CNN is about to have its day in court.

The US Justice Department's bid to block AT&T's $85 billion (Dh312 billion) merger with Time Warner is set to head to trial, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years. The deal, if approved, would create a media giant that combines AT&T's mobile and satellite distribution networks with Time Warner's huge collection of popular movies and television offerings, including "Game of Thrones" on HBO, news on CNN and college and professional basketball on TNT.

The central question of the trial: Would that combination hurt consumers or help them? How the judge rules in the case has the potential to shape the fast-changing business of video, as consumers increasingly turn to streaming services instead of traditional cable TV. AT&T, a nationwide satellite TV and wireless provider, argues that pairing up with a major content company is necessary to compete against the reach and resources of tech giants like Netflix and Amazon.

But the Justice Department says the deal would hurt upstart streaming services and lead to higher prices for consumers. The decision will frame the competition among Silicon Valley, Hollywood and Madison Avenue, while also establishing what kinds of corporate mergers — in the media industry and beyond — will be permitted in the years to come.

"This court case is so important it is hard to know where to start," said Amy Yong, a research analyst at the investment firm Macquarie. "This case is at the heart of what we do in our everyday lives."

The Justice Department's move to block the deal in November took Wall Street and the entertainment industry by surprise. Many executives and lawyers thought President Donald Trump's administration would usher in a hands-off approach to antitrust enforcement, despite Trump's criticism of the deal on the campaign trail.

Instead, the Justice Department, under its antitrust chief Makan Delrahim, moved aggressively, demanding the sale of major parts of the businesses before a deal could go through. AT&T responded by suggesting that Delrahim's decision was politically motivated and not based on established antitrust law. In recent weeks, though, the judge overseeing the case, Richard Leon of US District Court of the District of Columbia, has rejected moves by AT&T to inject politics into the arguments.

Unless the two sides settle — and there have been no signs of that happening — the trial is expected to showcase two starkly different visions of the US's video future.

Drama is also in the cards: Executives from AT&T and Time Warner, as well as competing cable, satellite, tech and media firms, are expected to take the stand — and possibly reveal details about the inner workings of the industry. The Justice Department argues that the merged company's combination of distribution and content would give it too much leverage in negotiations with the rest of the industry.

It also says that the new company would demand higher licensing fees from other cable and satellite firms for what the government calls "must-watch" programming. Those higher charges would immediately trickle down to consumers at an estimated cost of 45 cents a month, or a combined $436 million annually for cable and satellite subscribers, the agency said.

The government's case will be led by Craig Conrath, a plain-spoken and longtime litigator who has worked on merger cases for several administrations. He is expected to argue that if the merger is approved, AT&T and Comcast, a corporation that owns distribution and programming — the same combination that AT&T is seeking — would have the incentive to raise prices for access to their shows.

That would hurt other cable companies and online streaming businesses. Leon oversaw the final approval of Comcast's merger with NBCUniversal in 2011, the deal that added programming to Comcast's holdings.

"Either important video content will be available through a competitive market to all distributors, including up-and-coming innovators," the Justice Department said in pretrial filings. "Or it will likely only be available through vertically integrated, well-funded silos."

AT&T scoffs at the government's predictions of price increases. And even if the analysis is accurate, the company has said, it would amount to the price of a fancy cup of coffee for each consumer. Contrary to the government's theory that it would withhold content, AT&T says it wants to make sure its shows and movies are as widely distributed as possible.

Leading AT&T's defence is Daniel Petrocelli, a Los Angeles-based lawyer with a long track record in high-profile cases but not someone who is considered an antitrust expert. Petrocelli is expected to argue that the government is missing the bigger picture. AT&T says Silicon Valley companies like Netflix, Amazon, and Google have disrupted the entertainment industry by spending billions of dollars a year on original content and pushing the programming through their own distribution systems.

Facebook and Google dominate the market for advertisements that run with those videos. AT&T argues that a merger with Time Warner would add a new competitor against those giants, instead of reducing competition. AT&T will also promise to work out any contract disputes with cable and satellite companies through a third-party arbitrator, he is expected to argue.

"The new video revolution is defined by the spectacular rise of Netflix, Amazon, Google and other vertically integrated, direct-to-consumer technology companies," AT&T said in its pretrial brief.

The merger is opposed by several lawmakers and many consumer groups. Google, Facebook and Netflix, though mighty, don't own the pipes that connect people to the internet, they say. Streaming competition is the "best hope consumers have, but network operators will kill that competition if they are not stopped," said Mark Cooper, the director of research at the Consumer Federation of America.

--

Many Wall Street analysts, however, say the government's intervention in the deal will eventually harm consumers, because it will limit true competitors to the big tech companies. "The government is about three years behind reality and is defining the marketplace as it was about three years ago," said Laura Martin, an analyst at Needham & Co. AT&T had asked for detailed communications logs between the White House and Justice Department staff members, including Delrahim, a former Trump White House lawyer. Leon rejected those demands, and AT&T ultimately decided to exclude its concerns of potential presidential interference — which it described as "selective enforcement" — from the case. But even without arguments of political interference entering the trial, many on Wall Street will be looking for clues about the kinds of corporate deals that will pass muster during the Trump administration. The decision to block a merger between companies that don't directly compete is rare. Delrahim has said that one of the common regulatory remedies to prevent anti-competitive behaviour in such deals — getting companies to promise they'll be on their best behaviour — is not effective. That view may ripple across merger and acquisition plans in other sectors, including the drugstore chain CVS's $69 billion bid for the health insurance provider Aetna — as well as proposed media deals like Disney's acquisition of Fox and Sinclair Broadcasting's purchase of Tribune Media. Wall Street analysts expect the results of the trial will determine if more telecom and entertainment companies will pursue ambitious vertical mergers. "This could direct the future path of the industry," said Steven Salop, a professor of economics and law at Georgetown University Law School. "If it is permitted, vertical integration will continue."

- New York Times News Service
